attributes.title: Participatory Democracy as Electoral Base-Building: The Uses of Binding Participatory Institutions by Political Parties in Latin America

q1.value: Participatory Democracy as Electoral Base-Building: The Uses of Binding Participatory Institutions by Political Parties in Latin America

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Binding participatory institutions (BPIs) are key participatory institutions in Latin America that allow ordinary citizens to participate directly in decisions about the allocation of public resources. Their widespread implementation, however, depends on the support powerful institutional backers with strong incentives to support them. I argue that an important reason political parties are willing to invest resources in BPIs is the promise of reaping electoral benefits from them. In this study I examine both the ways in which parties incorporate BPIs into their electoral strategies, and the effects these BPI participation has on party identification, voter behavior, and volunteering in electoral campaigns. Answering these questions is essential for understanding the electoral strategies parties employ with respect to participatory institutions, and how those strategies fit into the broader landscape of electoral strategies.

q17.value: I test my theory of the ways parties incorporate BPIs into their electoral strategies and the effects of these strategies on party identification, voter behavior and electoral work through two original surveys in Venezuela. First, I survey 600 elected leaders of Venezuelan BPIs (voceros) from all 24 Venezuelan states. Second, I conduct a nationally-representative survey of 1200 Venezuela adults, oversampling for individuals who have participated in BPIs

registration_responses.q1: Participatory Democracy as Electoral Base-Building: The Uses of Binding Participatory Institutions by Political Parties in Latin America
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

First, I survey 600 elected leaders of Venezuelan BPIs (voceros) from all 24 Venezuelan states. Second, I conduct a nationally-representative survey of 1200 Venezuela adults, oversampling for individuals who have participated in BPIs

q2.value: Christian Grose | Pamela Lopez | Antoine Yoshinaka | Sara Sadhwani

q5.value: Comments on the theory and research design from WPSA participants and others to whom we emailed the design were appreciated.

q9.value: Experiment has been fielded by an outside group and data given to researchers, but outcome data not yet analyzed. The research design and pre-analysis plan were presented on April 3, 2015 at the WPSA prior to the experiment being fielded.

q15.value: Does direct lobbying cause elected officials to publicly endorse policy proposals, and is direct lobbying conducted in a social setting more effective than direct lobbying in a governmental setting? We theorize that direct lobbying will influence a legislator’s willingness to publicly support a policy proposal. We further theorize that social lobbying – where the "ask" occurs outside of a formal office visit – is more effective at causing legislators to take positions that are requested by the interest group’s lobbyist.

q16.value: We hypothesize that (1) direct lobbying in the early stages of the legislative process will lead legislators to be more publicly supportive of a policy; and (2) that social lobbying requests by interest groups outside of the office will be more effective than in-office lobbying. We also anticipate that both the in-office and social lobbying may be more effective conditional on the past working relationship between lobbyist and legislator (or lobbyist and legislative staff member) and/or whether the legislator is an ally of the interest group. Outcome variable: 1=legislator public supports policy; 0=legislator does not. This will be measured using legislator twitter, facebook, web site, and/or online press releases. Independent variables: Social lobby treatment: 1=legislative office was lobbied in a social setting outside of capitol building; 0=was not Office lobby treatment: 1=legislative office was lobbied in an office setting in capitol; 0=was not There is a control group not contacted. These groups are randomly assigned and implemented by group. To test the additional hypotheses, we will also condition these measures on observational variables: (a) perceived prior relationship between lobbyist and legislator office; and (b) legislator is ally of group. These will be measured as detailed in the April 2015 WPSA paper prior to the treatment with a survey question of the interest group staff. These variables will be interacted with the treatments given expectations that the direct lobbying (relative to control) and social lobbying will be more effective conditional on the group having a strong prior relationship and/or the elected official being an ally.

q17.value: The study will be conducted by an interest group in one U.S. state legislature. A group/lobbying firm conducted its planned lobbying campaign on a policy issue by dividing the subjects into three groups. The interest group contacted legislators in each of the three groups detailed above: social lobby treatment, office lobby treatment, and control group. These treatment contacts were randomized using block randomization (the block variable is the prior relationship between legislative office and lobbyist measured pre-treatment by survey of lobbyist pre-treatment). See details above and April 2015 WPSA paper for additional details. The group has asked this study be gated for some time due to the proprietary and sensitive nature of the policy request, and the group has asked to not be named in the pre-registration though scholars can provide details to any interested scholar.

q23.value: IRB ruled study is exempt research.

attributes.title: Political spillovers of the European migrant crisis

q1.value: Political spillovers of the European migrant crisis

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The context of this study is twofold: one is Denmark's referendum on abolishing the opt-out on EU justice and home affairs, which was called on August 21, 2015 to be held on December 3rd, 2015. The other context is the European migrant crisis, which erupted in the summer of 2015. Crucially, the migrant crisis only affected Denmark directly after the referendum was called, when about a week later large numbers of migrants came to Denmark from Germany, most of them wanting to pass through Denmark and apply for asylum in Sweden (or pass through Sweden and migrate further North). During the referendum campaign, it was widely discussed whether the migrant crisis affected the vote. This study uses proximity to the migrants' route through Denmark as a measure of exposure to the migrant crisis. I utilize two useful features: the migrants' route was largely confined to one specific highway (E47), and there was another EU-related referendum in 2014, providing a plausible pre-treatment measure for every polling place in the 2015 referendum. The outcome measure of the study, support for the EU referendum, will be at the polling place level. Because the migration issue is so politicized, I do not expect exposure to the migrant crisis to have uniform effects on support for the EU referendum. Instead, I expect it to depend on voters' predispositions, such that voters positively predisposed toward immigrants will react positively to exposure to the migrant crisis, and vice versa. As a measure of predispositions, I use support for the anti-immigrant party Danish People's Party, again at the polling place level.

q16.value: H1: Danish People's Party vote share interacts with migrant exposure such that higher (lower) DPP vote share is associated with a stronger negative (positive) effect of migrant exposure on EU support H2: Migrant exposure is associated with higher turnout

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested using OLS models on polling place data, aggregating returns from the 2014 and 2015 referenda as well as the 2015 general election.

q19.value: ca. 1400 polling places (full election returns, i.e. population data)

registration_responses.q1: Political spillovers of the European migrant crisis
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

During the referendum campaign, it was widely discussed whether the migrant crisis affected the vote. I utilize two useful features: the migrants' route was largely confined to one specific highway (E47), and there was another EU-related referendum in 2014, providing a plausible pre-treatment measure for every polling place in the 2015 referendum. The outcome measure of the study, support for the EU referendum, will be at the polling place level. registration_responses.q17: The hypotheses will be tested using OLS models on polling place data, aggregating returns from the 2014 and 2015 referenda as well as the 2015 general election.

attributes.title: Resource Distribution and Social Networks in DRC

q1.value: Resource Distribution and Social Networks in DRC

q2.value: Paul Hofman | Martha Maryse Ross | Maarten Voors

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: When distributing resources, development organizations want to have the widest reach with limited resources. This is often achieved through distribution of resources by the village chief or appointed committees (either existing or newly formed). We are interested in testing the direction and spread of information and resources through the village, and uptake. This research question is directly relevant to policy makers and development agencies if we find that social network characteristics are useful for predicting information and resource spread within communities. From an academic perspective understanding how social learning takes place is an important area of research within both development literature as well as social network literature.

q16.value: Are socially central ambassador better than isolate ambassadors at: -Increasing technology adoption -Increasing fertilizer knowledge -Increasing the Willingness to pay for fertilizer -Increasing the wideness of distribution in a village -Increasing the speed of diffusion -Decreasing the reduction in above effects as it gets further removed from the network entry point Do we see that the treatment effect tapers off if lower-stage ambassadors give the treatment for the following variables? -Fertilizer adoption -Fertilizer Knowledge -Willingness to Pay for fertilizer Which of the following variables can predict giving behaviour: -Social Distance -Physical Distance -Being blood family members -Being Field Neighbours -Discussing agriculture with each other -Eigenvector Centrality of the receiver -Difference in eigenvector centrality between sender and receiver -Age of the receiver -Sex of the receiver -Difference in sex -Whether receiver is a migrant -Income of the receiver -Difference in Income -Whether they are in a similar agricultural group -Whether they go to the same church

q17.value: We mapped full social networks in 40 remote villages in the east of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). Then, we trained several villagers in these villages in how to use chemical fertilizer, and gave them several bags of fertilizer. We asked them to distribute the fertilizer and the knowledge in the village. We randomly selected half of the villages to have the most central people as ambassadors, and the other half had the most isolate people as ambassadors. The only difference (if all goes well) between the two villages will be our ambassador assignment, allowing us to find the effect of ambassador centrality on our variables of interest. Furthermore, we asked the ambassadors to also train ambassadors themselves, who would then train and distribute to other people. This allows us to get higher levels of distribution, and allows us to observe the change in our outcome variables as it gets further away from the source. Finally, because we have expansive data on the relations between participants, we can use this result to examine if we can predict who ambassadors choose to share their knowledge and goods with.

q24.value: No number, but done by "Wageningen University Social Sciences Ethics Committee"

q1.value: Knowledge, attitudes and behaviour influencing adolescent pregnancy in Asia and the Pacific: A scoping review

q2.value: Dr Vanessa Sakalidis, Sarah Neal, Jo Sauvarin, Leah Bohle

q3.value:
Around 16 million adolescent girls aged 15-19 years give birth each year and nearly one million very young adolescents aged 10-14 give birth globally. Adolescent pregnancy has consistently been associated with adverse outcomes for both the young mother and infant  Delaying childbirth amongst adolescent girls is critical to avoiding the adverse outcomes of early childbearing, improving maternal, newborn and child health, as well as the educational and economic prospects of adolescent girls. In Asia and the Pacific, reducing adolescent pregnancy remains a major concern. South Asia, East Asia and the Pacific have the highest adolescent populations in the world, as well as high and stagnating adolescent birth rates, despite other countries globally benefiting from declining rates. 

Changes in urbanisation, globalisation and migration in Asia and the Pacific have contributed to shifting sexual values, norms and behaviours of adolescents, which have not been well investigated. Major gaps in knowledge in the region concerning sexually active adolescents (i.e. girls and boys), young adolescents aged 10-14 years and marginalized and vulnerable populations remain; particularly how their attitudes, behaviours and knowledge concerning sexual relationships, premarital sex, early marriage, and risk taking contribute to adolescent pregnancy. Understanding these gaps and how they contribute to adolescent pregnancy in Asia and the Pacific may help identify cultural and country-specific factors required to improve outcomes in the region.                   
                                                             
 This research thesis will investigate the knowledge, attitudes and behaviour of girls and boys influencing adolescent pregnancy rates in the Asia and Pacific region via a scoping review of peer-reviewed and grey literature. The scoping review aims to further understand how these factors influence adolescent pregnancy amongst the ages 10 to 19 in the region and contribute to an enhanced culturally specific understanding of factors contributing to adolescent pregnancy in differing contexts in Asia and the Pacific.

q4.value:
This study aims to further understand how knowledge, attitudes and behaviour of adolescents (10-19 years of age) influence adolescent pregnancy among girls/young women between 10-19 years of agein Asia and the Pacific through a scoping review of the literature: 

•	Objective 1: Understand how knowledge, attitudes and behaviour of adolescents girls and boys influence adolescent pregnancy in Asia and the Pacific.
•	Objective 2: Identify any differences in the knowledge, attitudes and behaviour influencing adolescent pregnancy between countries in Asia and the Pacific. 
•	Objective 3: Identify the gaps in the literature regarding the knowledge, attitudes and behaviour influence adolescent pregnancy in Asia and the Pacific.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A scoping literature review will be performed to further understand how knowledge, attitudes and behaviour of adolescent girls and boys influence adolescent pregnancy rates in Asia and the Pacific. Peer-reviewed and grey literature will be evaluated.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
In this scoping review, peer-reviewed and grey literature from 2009 to 2019 will be included. Databases searched will include PubMed, Scopus and Popline. Search terms will be combined in 4 key blocks based on 1) Adolescents, 2) Pregnancy 3) Knowledge, Attitudes and Behaviour and 4) Asia and the Pacific. Grey literature will be sourced through Popline and online reports. The review will follow the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) procedure of identification, screening and eligibility of the studies; a PRISMA flow chart will be created as an outcome. Quality will not be a criterion for inclusion for the scoping review; instead depth of the search in order to generate an overview of what is currently known and draw attention to areas where there are prominent knowledge gaps will be focused upon.

Eligibility criteria, studies must include:
•	Evidence relating to adolescent females and males including very young adolescents (10-14), or adolescents (10-19) based on the UN/WHO definition (3). 
•	Studies including young people (<10- 24) or youth (15-24) (3) will be additionally included if the population includes adolescents aged (10-19). 
•	Stated as an outcome, or measured as an outcome; adolescent pregnancy 
•	Study types: quantitative, qualitative or mixed methods, retrospective and prospective, research and implementation
•	Peer-reviewed published literature and grey literature including online reports only
•	 English literature only will be assessed
•	Time frame: 2009-2019
Measured at least one of these outcomes; 
•	Attitudes, or perceptions of sexual intercourse/relationships, pre-marital sex, early marriage/union influencing adolescent pregnancy 
•	Knowledge of sexuality, pregnancy and practices influencing adolescent pregnancy; 
•	Sexual behaviours and risky behaviours influencing adolescent pregnancy.
•	Geographic area: Low and middle income countries in Asia and the Pacific according to the Regional Office of the United Nations Population Fund Asia & the Pacific (UNFPA APRO). 


One researcher will conduct the systematic search and - in a first step, all returned titles/abstracts will be exported into Covidence software and after a duplication check they will be screened for eligibility for inclusion. Approximately 10% of screened titles/abstracts will be checked by the second reviewer and a kappa score for agreement will be calculated. The titles/abstracts that will be considered potentially eligible for inclusion will be kept for screening of full texts.  Two researchers will review and analyze the selected full texts for final inclusion in a blinded manner. The data extraction in Covidence will be conducted independently by screeners (with categories “in” and “out”), and then compared and discussed to reach a consensus. Selected articles will be reviewed and data will be abstracted. For each study, data will be collected on design, main outcome of interest, sample size, setting, population, comparison group (if available), inclusion and exclusion criteria, definitions, missing data, results, confounding factors, self-reported limitations of the study, funding sources and possible conflicts of interests.

Population:	Adolescents girls and boys 10-19 years 
Intervention:	Knowledge, attitudes and behaviours influencing adolescent pregnancy
Comparison 	None
Outcome:	Attitudes, or perceptions of sexual intercourse/relationships, pre-marital sex, early marriage/union, which may influence adolescent pregnancy
Knowledge of sexual health, pregnancy and practices which may influence adolescent pregnancy
Sexual behaviors, and risky behaviours which may influence adolescent pregnancy
Setting criteria:	Asia and the Pacific

A thematic analysis will be conducted to synthesize studies and compare outcomes by categorizing factors through a framework using a multi-level approach relating to knowledge, attitudes and behaviours. Additionally, where possible a country typology dealing with similar topics will be formulated with the available literature. A meta-analysis will not be performed.

attributes.title: Effect of imaginary social support on pain
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value:
Independent variable 1: Social support (alone vs. imaginary vs. real) - between-subject variable. Participants are randomly attributed to one condition
Independent variable 2: Self-reported attachment style (secure vs. anxious vs. avoidant)

question2b.value: Dependent variable: Participants rate how much pain they experience while their hand is immersed in a cold bucket by pointing to a number on a 10-point scale where 1 = none and 10 = extreme. Pain ratings are given every 20 seconds during a 3 minutes time laps

question10b.value:
Participants will be asked to come in pairs with a friend and to bring a picture of their friend. At the lab, each participant give their informed consent then fill various questionaire, among them one which measure their attachment style. Then, participant is invited to put his/her hand in a bucket of cold water and to report pain while doing it. Before doing that, they are randomly attributed to one of the following condition: 
- Participant is alone while putting one's hand in the bucket
- Participant has the friend's picture with her/him while putting the hand in the bucket and is invited to focus his/her attention on the picture while holding the hand in the bucket - moreover they're asked to imagine that their friend would support them. 
- Participants put their hand in the bucket while their friend is with them in the room and support them
-> Every particpant will be asked to hold their hand in the bucket during 3 minutes. Each 20 seconds, they give a number between 1 and 10 to  express their pain ratings. After, participants are debriefed and thanked.

question1a.value: We first predict a main effect of (imaginary) social support. More specifically, we predict that being alone results in higher reported pain to the cold pressor task than when being with a supportive individual or when imagining a supportive individual.

question2a.value: Second, we predict an interaction effects between attachment styles and (imaginary) social support: More specifically, we expect that when imagining a supportive individual, avoidant and secure participants will, compared to anxious individuals, report lower pain. However, when being with a supportive individual, we expect that secure and anxious participants will report lower pain than avoidant participants.

question1c.value:
- Attachment style questionnaire
- Social support: random attribution into three groups (real social support; imagined; alone)
- Self-reported pain: Participants indicate on a scale from 1 (very low) to 10 (very high) what degree of pain they feel. They report it every 20 seconds during a 3 minutes time lapse. Total : 9 measures of pain

registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question1a: We first predict a main effect of (imaginary) social support. More specifically, we predict that being alone results in higher reported pain to the cold pressor task than when being with a supportive individual or when imagining a supportive individual.
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question2a: Second, we predict an interaction effects between attachment styles and (imaginary) social support: More specifically, we expect that when imagining a supportive individual, avoidant and secure participants will, compared to anxious individuals, report lower pain. However, when being with a supportive individual, we expect that secure and anxious participants will report lower pain than avoidant participants.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a:
Independent variable 1: Social support (alone vs. imaginary vs. real) - between-subject variable. Participants are randomly attributed to one condition
Independent variable 2: Self-reported attachment style (secure vs. anxious vs. avoidant)
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b: Dependent variable: Participants rate how much pain they experience while their hand is immersed in a cold bucket by pointing to a number on a 10-point scale where 1 = none and 10 = extreme. Pain ratings are given every 20 seconds during a 3 minutes time laps
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
Participants will be asked to come in pairs with a friend and to bring a picture of their friend. At the lab, each participant give their informed consent then fill various questionaire, among them one which measure their attachment style. Then, participant is invited to put his/her hand in a bucket of cold water and to report pain while doing it. Before doing that, they are randomly attributed to one of the following condition: 
- Participant is alone while putting one's hand in the bucket
- Participant has the friend's picture with her/him while putting the hand in the bucket and is invited to focus his/her attention on the picture while holding the hand in the bucket - moreover they're asked to imagine that their friend would support them. 
- Participants put their hand in the bucket while their friend is with them in the room and support them
-> Every particpant will be asked to hold their hand in the bucket during 3 minutes. Each 20 seconds, they give a number between 1 and 10 to  express their pain ratings. After, participants are debriefed and thanked.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
- Attachment style questionnaire
- Social support: random attribution into three groups (real social support; imagined; alone)
- Self-reported pain: Participants indicate on a scale from 1 (very low) to 10 (very high) what degree of pain they feel. They report it every 20 seconds during a 3 minutes time lapse. Total : 9 measures of pain

IV: Time
IV: condition
Covariate: Sex
DV: Pain rating

q2.value: David Kirby | Donald Green | Alexander Coppock

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: We conduct a field experimental test of the effects of receiving the U.S. Constitution and Declaration of Independence in the mail approximately two weeks before the 2016 Presidential Election on turnout, vote choice, and political attitudes. We randomize at the level of the voting precinct, enabling us to infer effects on vote choice, an outcome that is unobservable at the individual level. We also measure the effects of the Constitution on attitudes by administering a post-election survey.

q16.value: Does receiving the Constitution stimulate voter participation? Does it affect vote choice? Does it affect political attitudes?

q17.value: Difference-in-means and covariate adjusted regression. We will cluster our standard errors by precinct (the level of random assignment). We will conduct statistical tests via randomization inference.

q27.value: The Cato Institute sent out the Constitutions

registration_responses.q2: David Kirby | Donald Green | Alexander Coppock
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q15: We conduct a field experimental test of the effects of receiving the U.S. Constitution and Declaration of Independence in the mail approximately two weeks before the 2016 Presidential Election on turnout, vote choice, and political attitudes. We randomize at the level of the voting precinct, enabling us to infer effects on vote choice, an outcome that is unobservable at the individual level. We also measure the effects of the Constitution on attitudes by administering a post-election survey.

registration_responses.q17: Difference-in-means and covariate adjusted regression. We will cluster our standard errors by precinct (the level of random assignment). We will conduct statistical tests via randomization inference.
registration_responses.q27: The Cato Institute sent out the Constitutions

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Little is known about people why people view political fact-checking content or whether such content is effective in better informing the public about controversial political statements and issues. This study will evaluate how fact-check readers and the general public in Italy view fact-checking, how interested they are in reading it when offered alternate content options, and what effects it has on what they know about politics. Specifically, we examine how different audiences select and respond to information from the Italian fact-checking website Pagella Politica, contrasting the behavior of readers of Pagella Politica and other Italian news sites with a general population sample. Respondents are given a list of articles to choose from and then asked respondents which article they would choose to read. We experimentally vary aspects of this choice to see how it affects the article(s) that people indicate they would like to read. We will also randomize whether respondents are assigned to the articles they would choose to read or not, allowing us to contrast the effects of assigned exposure to fact-checking with the effects when people have an option to select non-political news instead.

q16.value: H1: Selective exposure We expect that people will not choose to read negative fact-checks about a favored party as much as those about a disfavored party. In this study, the fact-checks included in the study as treatments have a middle-ground rating of “Ni” (an Italian idiom that combines “No” and “Si”). Our specific expectation is that respondents will be more likely to read a fact-check of a statement from a party that they do not identify with or feel positively toward (H1a) and that providing a graphic indicating that the rating is mixed will increase the prevalence of this type of selective exposure (H1b). These effects may vary by political sophistication (i.e., knowledge) or sample - i.e., general population vs. Pagella Politica/Italian news site reader (RQ1). We also are interested to see if people are inclined to select fact-checks about the issue they see as the most important problem (RQ2a), which is our primary measure of issue salience, and whether selective exposure is greater on high-salience issues of this type (RQ2b). Finally, our study looks at results from two different samples -- a sample of Italian fact-check readers and a sample from a web-based panel of Italians. We expect that fact-check readers will select fact-checks more often than respondents from our general Italian sample. H2 and H3: Differential learning effects Our design asks people to select the content they are interested in, and separately randomizes what content people receive. While we discuss the design in more detail below, key features are necessary to explain our hypotheses. Respondents are assigned to one of three conditions -- receive fact-checking content regardless of which content they would prefer (25%), receive entertainment content regardless of the content they prefer (25%), or receive the content they prefer (50%). On average, we expect that exposure to fact-checking leads to learning about politics. Thus, our overall expectations are that respondents in the assigned exposure condition will learn more than those in the content choice condition relative to the control group (H2). We also expect learning effects to be lower for counter-attitudinal information than for pro-attitudinal information in the assigned exposure condition (H3a) and when comparing learning in the the content choice condition and assigned exposure conditions relative to the control group (H3b). The selective exposure and resistance effects described in H2 and H3 are likely to be greatest in the general population sample, which is less interested in political news; readers of a fact-checking site should be more likely to accept counter-attitudinal findings (RQ3).

q17.value: We adopt a variant of a doubly randomized preference trial (DRPT) design similar to Arceneaux, Johnson, and Murphy (2012) in which some respondents are randomized to receive a treatment or control and others are allowed to choose their condition. In this case, the treatment is exposure to fact-checking. We also experimentally test the effects of fact-checking graphics on tendencies to engage in selective exposure when choosing political news to consume at the article (rather than outlet) level. Please see the attached pre-registration and analysis plan document for more details.

q24.value: Yes. This study was approved by the CPHS at Dartmouth (STUDY00029103) and the University of Exeter SSIS Ethics Committee (reference #201516-025).

attributes.title: An Experiment on the Interaction of Violence and Obedience

q1.value: An Experiment on the Interaction of Violence and Obedience

q2.value: Carolyn Coberly | Megan A. Stewart | Todd S. Sechser

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: This experiment will examine the micro-foundations of the eectiveness of violence against civilians by testing whether, and under what conditions, exposure to violence make individuals more or less likely to obey authority.

q16.value: H1: Individuals who witness violence will be more likely to obey all commands than individuals who have not been exposed to violence. H2: Individuals who witness violence will be more likely to obey pro-social commands than other types of commands, relative to individuals who have not been exposed to violence. H3: Individuals who witness violence will be more likely to obey anti-social commands than other types of commands, relative to individuals who have not been exposed to violence.

q17.value: There are two treatments for this experiment: The violence treatment consists of a 10-minute video of images of real violence (including rioting, bombing, and executions) obtained from YouTube. The control for this treatment is a 10-minute video of neutral imagery (calm nature scenes, for example). The obedience treatment consists of recorded commands delivered to participants individually via headphones. During six rounds of a 10-round combined dictator/joy-of-destruction game, participants will receive one of two instructions: a command to destroy the income of another participant (anti-social command) or to give some of their income to another participant (pro-social command). The control for this treatment will be an equal number of sessions in which no commands are given. Participants will therefore be randomized into one of six equal-sized groups (Violence/No Command, Violence/Pro-social command, Violence/Anti-social command, No Violence/No Command, No Violence/Pro-Social Command, No Violence, Anti-Social Command). If Hypothesis 1 is correct, then the average number of people who obey both pro- and anti-social commands after watching the violence treatment (who give after receiving a command to give and destroy after receiving a command to destroy) should be higher than the average number of people who obey a command after watching the control video. If Hypothesis 2 is correct, then participants who receive the violence treatment will be more likely to obey pro-social commands and more likely to disobey anti-social commands than those not exposed to violence. If Hypothesis 3 is correct, then participants exposed to violence will be more likely to obey anti-social commands and more likely to disobey pro-social commands than those not exposed to violence.

H3: Individuals who witness violence will be more likely to obey anti-social commands than other types of commands, relative to individuals who have not been exposed to violence.

If Hypothesis 3 is correct, then participants exposed to violence will be more likely to obey anti-social commands and more likely to disobey pro-social commands than those not exposed to violence.

attributes.title: Strategies for Stress Reduction to Address Support for Political Violence and Extremism

q1.value: Strategies for Stress Reduction to Address Support for Political Violence and Extremism

q2.value: Daphna Canetti | Joshua Gubler | Eran Zaidese | Thomas Zeitzoff

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: A large body of research in political psychology connects exposure to political violence to stress, and subsequent support for political violence and political extremism. We seek to test whether different psychological techniques for reducing stress--cognitive behavior therapy (CBT) or deep breathing--can separately or in conjunction reduce support for political violence and extremism. We plan to conduct a survey experiment testing whether different strategies of stress reduction reduce support for political extremism within the context of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict--considered one of the most intractable ongoing conflicts. One of the defining features of the conflict has been the large role that civilian victimization and subsequent stress and fear have played in influencing political opinion. We will test our proposition on a nationally-diverse sample of Jewish Israelis.

q16.value: Our main hypotheses are related to our stress reduction treatments outlined below. Subjects will be randomly assigned to one of the four treatments 1. CBT+ Breathing: Discusses the benefits of CBT AND has students engage in deep breathing for 2-3 minutes. 2. CBT+ Cognitive Practice: Discusses the benefits of CBT and has students engage in a CBT re-appraisal task. 3. Placebo (talking about what they ate): 4. CBT Only: Discusses the benefits of CBT for changing how to think. Hypotheses H1 Individuals assigned to the CBT treatments will have lower support for political violence/use of force against Palestinians than those assigned to the Placebo H2 Individuals assigned to the CBT treatments will be more supportive of minority rights for Palestinians than those assigned to the Placebo H3 Individuals assigned to the CBT treatments will be less supportive of extra-judicial punishments of Palestinians than those assigned to the Placebo Research Questions (Hypotheses we are less sure about) RQ1 The different CBT treatments (CBT Only vs. CBT Breathing vs. CBT Practice) will have different effect sizes relative to each other. RQ2 Partisanship will moderate the response to the treatments, with left-wing Israelis responding differently to the CBT treatments than right-wing Israelis RQ3 People with high levels of anxiety will be more responsive to the CBT treatments (greater reduction in extremism and support for violence) than those with lower levels of stress and anxiety. RQ4 Individual level of victimization will also moderate the treatment. RQ5 Individuals assigned to the CBT treatments will be less supportive of an aggressive foreign policy than those assigned to the Placebo. RQ6 Individuals assigned to the CBT treatments will be more supportive of compromise and peaceful measures to end the Israeli-Palestinian conflict than those assigned to the Placebo. R6 Individuals assigned to the CBT treatments will be more understanding of Arab/Palestinian motivations for violence (less likely to view actions motivated by hatred) than those assigned to the Placebo. R7 Individuals assigned to the CBT treatments will be less understanding/tolerant of Jewish extremist violence (more likely to view actions motivated by hatred) than those assigned to the Placebo. R8 Levels of trait aggression will moderate the effect of the CBT treatments, with more aggressive individuals being less responsive to the CBT treatments.

q17.value: These hypotheses will be tested in the context of our online survey experiment. Subjects will be randomly assigned to one of the four treatments. Following, the treatments they will answer questions related to their views on counter-terror operations, motivations for Palestinian attacks, tolerance for minority rights/racism, punishment for ingroup members (Jews) who transgress, extrajudicial punishments/torture, attitudes on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and general foreign policy attitudes. Additional questions will be asked on individual religious attendance, political orientation, and past level of victimization

q24.value: American University IRB #2016-110 Brigham Young University IRB #E15410 University of Haifa Ethics #297/15

q25.value: American University: 10/30/15 Brigham Young University: 11/2/15 University of Haifa : 10/29/15

q27.value: The Midgam Project http://www.midgampanel.com/research/en/academicResearch.asp will handle the sampling, random assignment, and data collection. The authors will perform the statistical analyses.
